thread.title: H.S. field hockey: Wayne Hills wins title - Field Hockey
thread.title_full: H.S. field hockey: Wayne Hills wins title - Field Hockey - NorthJersey.com

author: DAVE MEISEL
title: H.S. field hockey: Wayne Hills wins title - Field Hockey
text:
WAYNE – A field hockey county championship three-peat was completed by Wayne Hills on Friday, but a "dynasty" was not born.
The Patriots’ feeling is their 2013, 2014 and 2015 Passaic County championships are compartmentalized and distinct from one another, and that Friday’s 1-0 victory over Pompton Lakes was the sweetest of the bunch.
"There’s been a different feeling each year and that word [dynasty] is not one we want to use," said coach Tina Londino. "At the beginning of the year, I might not have seen this coming."
The previous two years, the Patriots were a top team thanks to their pure talent, but this year required more learning and effort.
"I saw all the work that had to be done in the off-season and all the learning we had to do," Londino said. "But it’s amazing and I am so proud of these girls that they kept working as hard as they could and with the heart and intensity that they showed."
The players also have no use for the dynasty cliché.
"You can’t look at things in terms of legacy. Every year is different," said Amy Prol, a member of all three title-winning teams.
"It was more fulfilling, the win this year," added Liz Byrne, also a part of the three titles.
The game was, as expected, a defensive struggle. There was little open space to be found, much less open shot attempts. Amanda Fortemps turned in a great effort at right midfield, as did Alison Duffy at left back for the Patriots. Allison Badami and Prol had major defensive impacts, including Prol’s key clearance moments before the goal.
The goal could not have been scripted better. Byrne, after being lauded all year for her efforts despite Amanda LaGuardia doing most of the Patriots’ scoring, scored the winner with 10 minutes remaining in regulation.
"It doesn’t really matter to me to show up in the box score," Byrne said, "the fact that the team came together is more important."
"We’re not certainly going to give up now, we want to advance in the state tournament," Prol said.
